channel.title: New sig
channel.description:
Followed a tutorial on gamerenders only for the smudging background!!! Cos I really needed some good smudging settings. The rest is all mine.
Quite proud of it actually and I'll probably make some more this evening (once i master the clipping mask... whatever that is (someone tell me please!!!)).
[img]http://img260.imageshack.us/img260/113/sigwtextpe1.png[/img]

item.title: New sig
item.dc:creator: @Sick_of_Air Sick of Air
item.description:
@Sick_of_Air wrote:

TBH, I don’t know why it’s called a clipping mask xD

Read full topic

item.title: New sig
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

I swear on my life I have never used a clipping mask. And I was acting like a bit of a prick. Also I have no idea why I didn’t capitalise my "i"s in that first quote. I always go through my post looking for little ones before I post it. Guess I was in a rush.

Firefox spell checker is really annoying. It says I spelt “capitalise” wrong because I didn’t use a “z”! I hate it!

Sick of Air:

Goatee, a clipping mask is usually just an apply image that is attached to the font and then moved around. You do it by placing your text, then making a new layer. Then you hide the text and do an apply image on the empty layer. Now unhide your text and with the apply image layer selected, press CTRL + ALT + g, and then just move around the apply image layer. That’s the most commonly used use of a clipping mask as far as I know. I probably didn’t explain it very well though xD

Oh wow… so that’s how people blend there text. I did apply image then duplicated that then put the text in the middle and erased the top applied image to show the text then smudged it over the gap a bit. I’m gonna have to try a clipping mask. Why is it called that?

Read full topic

goatee:

Thanks for the comments… [size=1pt]someone tell me what a clipping mask is and how to use it!!! please [/size]

I had the feeling you where not goatee, since he has used Clipping Mask in the past, and he uses grammar ;\

item.title: New sig
item.dc:creator: @Sick_of_Air Sick of Air
item.description:
@Sick_of_Air wrote:

Goatee, a clipping mask is usually just an apply image that is attached to the font and then moved around. You do it by placing your text, then making a new layer. Then you hide the text and do an apply image on the empty layer. Now unhide your text and with the apply image layer selected, press CTRL + ALT + g, and then just move around the apply image layer. That’s the most commonly used use of a clipping mask as far as I know. I probably didn’t explain it very well though xD
